render.tex: \title{Binomial Distribution} Getting $r$ heads in $n$ coin flips

reason.tex:
%text Imagine a task (like flipping a coin) that could either be a success (getting heads) or a failure (getting tails) If this task is done $n$ times, then what is the probability of getting $r$ successes? If we were to write the probabilities out, then we would get a table like the one below % \begin{align} \begin{tabular}{NNNNN}
\hline r & 0 & 1 & \ldots & n \\ \hline P(r) & p_0 & p_1 & \ldots & p_n \\ \hline \end{tabular} \end{align} %text Notice that this is simply a probability distribution. But it goes by a special name -- binomial distribution That said, $P(r)$ in the table above is \[P(r) = ^nC_r\cdot p^r\cdot q^{(n-r)} \text{ where } q = 1- p \] %
